description:
Ubuntu Oneiric, KVM, devstack.

While booting identical images, I got the below error on boot from one of the instances.  Booting again from the same image does work.  I looked for any error messages in /var/log or anything different, I couldn't find anything.

I'm guessing this is a KVM bug, though my google-fu is not up to finding any bug reports for KVM because I think this happens all the time whenever the image is mismatched.  That isn't the case here though, because booting another instance from the same image works.

Error printed during boot:

This kernel requires the following features not present on the CPU:
fpu msr pae cx8 cmov fxsr sse sse2
Unable to boot - please use a kernel appropriate for your CPU
title: Random KVM boot failure: 'This kernel requires the following features not present on the CPU'

comments.content:
Ubuntu Oneiric, KVM, devstack.

While booting identical images, I got the below error on boot from one of the instances.  Booting again from the same image does work.  I looked for any error messages in /var/log or anything different, I couldn't find anything.

I'm guessing this is a KVM bug, though my google-fu is not up to finding any bug reports for KVM because I think this happens all the time whenever the image is mismatched.  That isn't the case here though, because booting another instance from the same image works.

Error printed during boot:

This kernel requires the following features not present on the CPU:
fpu msr pae cx8 cmov fxsr sse sse2
Unable to boot - please use a kernel appropriate for your CPU
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~justin-fathomdb

comments.content:
Can you include your /proc/cpuinfo?

Thanks
chuck
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~zulcss

comments.content: We cannot solve the issue you reported without more information. Could you please provide the requested information ?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content:
I am also seeing the exact problem and able to reproduce it consistently (happens only once in 15 to 25 attempts).
Here is my /proc/cpuinfo (showing only 1 core, out of the 8 cores (16 cpus with HT-enabled)) .

-----------------------

processor       : 0
vendor_id       : GenuineIntel
cpu family      : 6
model           : 45
model name      : Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2665 0 @ 2.40GHz
stepping        : 7
cpu MHz         : 2399.886
cache size      : 20480 KB
physical id     : 0
siblings        : 8
core id         : 0
cpu cores       : 8
apicid          : 0
initial apicid  : 0
fpu             : yes
fpu_exception   : yes
cpuid level     : 13
wp              : yes
flags           : fpu vme de pse tsc msr pae mce cx8 apic sep mtrr pge 
mca cmov pat pse36 clflush dts acpi mmx fxsr sse sse2 ss ht tm pbe syscall nx pdpe1gb rdtscp lm constant_tsc arch_perfmon pebs bts rep_good nopl xtopology nonstop_tsc aperfmperf pni pclmulqdq dtes64 monitor ds_cpl vmx smx est tm2 ssse3 cx16 xtpr pdcm dca sse4_1 sse4_2 x2apic popcnt aes xsave avx lahf_lm ida arat epb xsaveopt pln pts dts tpr_shadow vnmi flexpriority ept vpid
bogomips        : 4799.77
clflush size    : 64
cache_alignment : 64
address sizes   : 46 bits physical, 48 bits virtual
power management:
------------------------------------

Hope this helps.  It looks like, over time, upon multiple 'start and shutdowns' of the VM, at some point the 'cpu-flags'  being passed to the kernel are getting wacked.  (not sure, just my suspecion).
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~bcj01

comments.content:
Interesting that this is so intermittent

We really need details on what version of various packages are involved here - i.e. the versions of Nova, libvirt, qemu, host kernel, what guest image is being used, etc.

This problem may have gone away in Folsom since we're now defaulting to the "host model" CPU mode. See:

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/libvirt-xml-cpu-model
http://berrange.com/posts/2010/02/15/guest-cpu-model-configuration-in-libvirt-with-qemukvm/
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~markmc

comments.content: We cannot solve the issue you reported without more information. Could you please provide the requested information ?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~russellb

comments.content: This bug lacks the necessary information to effectively reproduce and fix it, therefore it has been closed. Feel free to reopen the bug by providing the requested information and set the bug status back to ''New''.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content: The bug still exists in the latest Folsom release when using libvirt_cpu_mode of host-model. Answering the questions in #4: Nova version of 2012.2.1, libvirt's version is 0.10.2, qemu's version is 1.2.0, host kernel of 3.0.51, and the guest image is SLES11 SP1 with kernel 2.6.32.59-0.7-default.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cskelly

comments.content: This also happened with a SLES11 SP2 image using kernel 3.0.51-0.7.9-default. The image was booted three times: first time successful, second time failed, and third time successfully on the same physical machine as where it failed.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cskelly

comments.content:
Where can I get the SLES11 SP2 image that you are using so I can try to reproduce this?

thanks
chuck
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~zulcss

comments.content: This bug also affects a SLES11 SP0 image running kernel 2.6.27.19-5 on a different physical host.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~cskelly

comments.content: Is this still a problem with the latest OpenStack release?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~thang-pham

comments.content: IIRC Suse actually does some really clever on their graphics boot which was actually really hard to handle in Xen guests. I kind of wonder if that's an issue with the old kvm that was used here. Anyway, I don't think this is an OpenStack bug per say.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~sdague
